newsitem.title: USA: Former U.S. soldier gets life in race killings.
newsitem.headline: Former U.S. soldier gets life in race killings.

text.p: A white former U.S. Army paratrooper convicted in the racially motivated killings of a black couple was sentenced Monday to two life prison terms without parole.

North Carolina Superior Court Judge Coy Brewer imposed the two life sentences on Malcolm Wright after a jury recommended he be given life in prison instead of the death penalty for the murder of Jackie Burden and Michael James on Dec. 7, 1995.

On May 2, Wright was found guilty of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder in the shooting deaths of Burden and James as part of an initiation ritual for a white supremacist group at Fort Bragg.
The jury made its recommendation after a short deliberation. Earlier, Brewer had released three alternate jurors, all women.

One of them, Patricia Gilligan, a Wilmington teacher, commented on how difficult it was to serve during such a trial. "We are jurors, being put in this position, to sit in judgment in something so horrendous was extremely stressful. We just could not believe that somebody was capable of such a thing," she said.

Wright, 22, of Lexington, Kentucky, was charged along with fellow soldier James Burmeister, 21. Burmeister was convicted and sentenced to life in prison earlier this year after a jury deadlocked 11-1 in favour of executing him.
